Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is expanding Advanced Technological Education Television's (ATETV) (www.atetv.org) impact by producing bilingual student recruitment and retention videos featuring and aimed at Hispanics and Latinos. This video series is also advancing knowledge of effective recruitment strategies and understanding of career choice processes across many ATE disciplines. The work is being developed and created using the input and resources of educational partners with experience in the Hispanic and Latino communities and is being tested for efficacy under controlled circumstances in multiple venues. The shifting demographics of our nation make this work imperative. Embracing and engaging students who may be the only English speakers in their homes, or for whom Spanish is their first language is inviting Hispanics and Latinos, the largest ethnic minority in the US, to learn about STEM education and technology careers with the ultimate goal of improving the diversity of qualified technicians across a broad range of science and technology. This new series of videos is creating fresh and comprehensive content focusing on the wide range of opportunities in STEM, and is leveraging existing content (created for ATETV) to expand the reach of this material and generate new understanding of ATE educational and career pathways. These bilingual videos have multiple audio tracks (English and Spanish), multiple subtitle tracks and are highlighting emerging technical disciplines that are helping close some content gaps in the prior ATETV work.

ATETV Bilingual Series extends across ATE disciplines and benefits Hispanic students and families, educators and high school guidance counselors. The videos are enhancing the recruitment efforts of technician educators, improving diversity in the workforce, improving educational attainment and employment for Hispanics and modeling processes for others to follow whether they are targeting Hispanics or other underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hispanic and Latino Americans remain under-enrolled in STEM education and underrepresented in STEM careers. Research demonstrates that recruitment efforts began in formative educational years, particularly in high school, and that in order to create a pathway toward STEM education and STEM technician careers, these efforts must include not only the student, but also resonate with the student’s family, who maintain substantial influence into the student’s educational and career decisions.

The under-enrollment and underrepresentation of Hispanic and Latino Americans in post-secondary courses and STEM technician careers highlights the need for this project.

The goal of this project was to increase pathways for Hispanic and Latino students to explore educational requirements for post-secondary technician education and careers in STEM, and ultimately effectuate increased enrollment in technician education programs and STEM technician careers. Working on and extending the success of ATETV, project outcomes included creation of an expanded video series featuring and aimed at Hispanic and Latino audiences.

These videos engage Hispanic and Latino audiences, develop awareness and understanding of two and four year college and university technology programs and requirements for specific technician careers, highlight STEM education and careers, and examine the educational preparation required, beginning in high school, in order to succeed in post-secondary STEM education and STEM careers. Project outcomes included the creation of 36 videos, available online at www.ATETV.org and on ATETV’s YouTube channel. The high­ quality videos created are also suitable for broadcast and/or professional use, and downloadable at no cost and without copyright infringement, for use in all media in perpetuity. Throughout the United States, the videos created as a result of this award are currently in use at several high schools, colleges, including ATETV’s educational partners, and at public access television channels. Videos showcase STEM educational pathways and career opportunities.

Further, educators requested a streamlined access specifically to the bilingual videos on ATETV, and as a result, project outcomes also included creating a single repository of these videos, with uploaded transcripts and original footage, at: https://sites.google.com/a/pelletproductions.com/atetv­educacion­tecnica/video­ segments. Educators use these resources in their recruitment efforts. Videos can be streamed on Internet connected devices and can be downloaded to local computers providing educators greater flexibility in their use.

These results indicate that the bilingual video series serves as a resource through which educators may have a positive influence in shifting the perspective on Hispanic and Latino American education in STEM and STEM technician careers.
